title: How to Make a String Covered Jar

steps.headline: Dab a little glue onto the rim area of the jar to begin the project.
steps.description: Glue one end of the string in place. Let it dry before proceeding with the winding of the string.

steps.headline: When dry, begin winding the string around the jar.
steps.description: Using the sponge brush, apply some glue to the first section around the jar. Wrap the string around this area, taking care to keep the string closely aligned with each prior row; no gaps!

steps.headline: Work your way down the jar.
steps.description: Paint on a section of glue, wrap the string, then paint on another section, wind again, and so forth.

steps.headline: Keep winding until you reach the end of the jar.
steps.description: Cut the string off when it can't be wound into place on the side of the jar any further. Tuck against the edge neatly to finish off and add extra glue to make the end firm.

steps.headline: Use.
steps.description: It can now be used for flowers, pencils, utensils, or anything else you'd like to keep inside it.

steps.headline: Plan ahead how many different colors you'd like to add and in what pattern.
steps.description:
Some suggestions include:
Alternating two colors of even widths down the length of the jar. Adding one, two or three differently colored stripes, of varying or equal widths, in the middle of the jar. Placing different color stripes at the beginning and end. Any other variant of your own choosing.

steps.headline: Follow the first two steps of the previous method.
steps.description:
However, then make these changes:
Estimate the placement of the differently colored string stripes. When you reach the different sections, cut off the current piece of string you're working with and carefully tuck up against the previous row. Glue firmly in place. Glue the new colored string in place. Wait until it dries before wrapping it around. Finish wrapping when that section is done. Cut off and glue firmly in place, pushing up against the prior row. Add the next string by gluing in place, waiting for it to dry, then wrapping again. Repeat each time a section color needs to change, following your pattern.

steps.headline: Finish off by cutting the last section's string off when it can't be wound into place on the side of the jar any further.
steps.description: Tuck against the edge neatly to finish off and add extra glue to make the end firm.

steps.headline: Use.
steps.description: As with the one color string jar, this can now be used for flowers, pencils, utensils, or anything else you'd like to keep inside it.

text:
One color string jar Dab a little glue onto the rim area of the jar to begin the project. Glue one end of the string in place. Let it dry before proceeding with the winding of the string. When dry, begin winding the string around the jar. Using the sponge brush, apply some glue to the first section around the jar. Wrap the string around this area, taking care to keep the string closely aligned with each prior row; no gaps! Work your way down the jar. Paint on a section of glue, wrap the string, then paint on another section, wind again, and so forth. Keep winding until you reach the end of the jar. Cut the string off when it can't be wound into place on the side of the jar any further. Tuck against the edge neatly to finish off and add extra glue to make the end firm. Use. It can now be used for flowers, pencils, utensils, or anything else you'd like to keep inside it. Multi-colored string jar variation Plan ahead how many different colors you'd like to add and in what pattern. Some suggestions include:
Alternating two colors of even widths down the length of the jar. Adding one, two or three differently colored stripes, of varying or equal widths, in the middle of the jar. Placing different color stripes at the beginning and end. Any other variant of your own choosing. Follow the first two steps of the previous method. However, then make these changes:
Estimate the placement of the differently colored string stripes. When you reach the different sections, cut off the current piece of string you're working with and carefully tuck up against the previous row. Glue firmly in place. Glue the new colored string in place. Wait until it dries before wrapping it around. Finish wrapping when that section is done. Cut off and glue firmly in place, pushing up against the prior row. Add the next string by gluing in place, waiting for it to dry, then wrapping again. Repeat each time a section color needs to change, following your pattern. Finish off by cutting the last section's string off when it can't be wound into place on the side of the jar any further. Tuck against the edge neatly to finish off and add extra glue to make the end firm. Use. As with the one color string jar, this can now be used for flowers, pencils, utensils, or anything else you'd like to keep inside it.
